data.name: Description
data.value: This module can send email after an operation completes

data.name: Displayname
data.value: Send mail

data.name: FailedToLookupMXServer
data.value: Unable to find the destination mail server through MX lookup, please use the option {0} to specify what smtp server to use.

data.name: OptionBodyLong
data.value:
This value can be a filename. If a the file exists, the file contents will be used as the message body.
In the message body, certain tokens are replaced: %OPERATIONNAME% - The name of the operation, normally "Backup" %REMOTEURL% - Remote server url %LOCALPATH% - The path to the local files or folders involved in the operation (if any)
All commandline options are also reported within %value%, e.g. %volsize%. Any unknown/unset value is removed.

data.name: OptionBodyShort
data.value: The message body

data.name: OptionPasswordLong
data.value: The password used to authenticate with the SMTP server if required.

data.name: OptionPasswordShort
data.value: SMTP Password

data.name: OptionRecipientLong
data.value:
This setting is required if mail should be sent, all other settings have default values. You can supply multiple email adresses seperated with commas, and you can use the normal adress format as specified by RFC2822 section 3.4. Example with 3 recipients:
Peter Sample <peter@example.com>, John Sample <john@example.com>, admin@example.com

data.name: OptionRecipientShort
data.value: Email recipient(s)

data.name: OptionSendallLong
data.value: By default, mail will only be sent after a Backup operation. Use this option to send mail for all operations.

data.name: OptionSendallShort
data.value: Send email for all operations

data.name: OptionSenderLong
data.value:
Adress of the email sender. If no host is supplied, the hostname of the first recipient is used. Examples of allowed formats:
sender sender@example.com Mail Sender <sender> Mail Sender <sender@example.com>

data.name: OptionSenderShort
data.value: Email sender

data.name: OptionSendlevelLong
data.value: You can specify one of "{0}", "{1}", "{2}". You can supply multiple options with a comma seperator, e.g. "{0},{1}". The special value "{3}" is a shorthand for "{0},{1},{2}" and will cause all backup operations to send an email.

data.name: OptionSendlevelShort
data.value: The messages to send

data.name: OptionServerLong
data.value:
A url for the SMTP server, e.g. smtp://example.com:25. Multiple servers can be supplied in a prioritized list, seperated with semicolon. If a server fails, the next server in the list is tried, until the message has been sent. If no server is supplied, a DNS lookup is performed to find the first recipient's MX record, and all SMTP servers are tried in their priority order until the message is sent.
To enable TLS, use the format smtptls://example.com or tls://example.com. If no port is specified, port 25 is used for non-ssl, and 587 for SSL connections. Note that only TLS/STARTTLS is supported and not SMTP over SSL.

data.name: OptionServerShort
data.value: SMTP Url

data.name: OptionSubjectLong
data.value: This setting supplies the email subject. Values are replaced as described in the description for --{0}.

data.name: OptionSubjectShort
data.value: The email subject

data.name: OptionUsernameLong
data.value: The username used to authenticate with the SMTP server if required.

data.name: OptionUsernameShort
data.value: SMTP Username

data.name: SendMailFailedError
data.value: Failed to send email: {0}

data.name: SendMailFailedRetryError
data.value: Failed to send email with server: {0}, message: {1}, retrying with {2}

data.name: SendMailSuccess
data.value: Email sent successfully using server: {0}
